title: Know Your Kit
description: Explore all 8 drum pads and learn what each percussion sound is used for.

steps.title: Your Drum Kit
steps.description:
A standard drum kit has several key pieces. In Micro DAW, you have 8 pads:

• KCK (Kick) — the deep bass drum, played with a foot pedal
• SNR (Snare) — the sharp crack that drives the beat
• CHH (Closed Hi-hat) — tight, ticking cymbal for rhythm
• OHH (Open Hi-hat) — looser, ringing cymbal
• CLP (Clap) — a hand clap accent
• TOM (Tom) — mid-pitched drum for fills
• CRS (Crash) — loud cymbal for accents
• RDE (Ride) — steady cymbal for keeping time

steps.title: Hit the Kick
steps.description: The kick drum is the foundation of every beat. Hit the KCK pad.
steps.hint: KCK is pad 0 — the red pad.

steps.title: Hit the Snare
steps.description: The snare drum provides the 'crack' on beats 2 and 4. Hit the SNR pad.
steps.hint: SNR is pad 1 — the orange pad.

steps.title: Hit the Closed Hi-hat
steps.description: The closed hi-hat keeps the pulse going with a tight 'tick' sound. Hit CHH.

steps.title: Hit the Open Hi-hat
steps.description: The open hi-hat has a longer, ringing sound. It adds variety to hi-hat patterns. Hit OHH.

steps.title: Hit the Clap
steps.description: Claps are used in pop, hip-hop, and electronic music — often layered with or replacing the snare. Hit CLP.

steps.title: Hit the Tom
steps.description: Toms are used for drum fills — the exciting transitions between sections. Hit TOM.

steps.title: Hit the Crash
steps.description: Crash cymbals mark the beginning of new sections with a loud, explosive sound. Hit CRS.

steps.title: Hit the Ride
steps.description: The ride cymbal provides a steady, shimmering pulse. It's often used instead of hi-hats. Hit RDE.
